Triggering Event: After an exhausting 12-hour shift, she returns home to find the answering machine blinking with messages from well-meaning friends asking when she's ready for another blind date. She slams her fist on the counter, scattering mail. "Why can't they understand? It's only been a year."
Generated Assessment: She feels as if every single one of those people is trying to be her friend just so they could have sex with her. They're all trying to hook up with her in some way - it doesn’t matter how many times she says no. It’s always this way. No matter how many times she tells them that she’s not interested, they keep coming back with more dates. And even after she says no again and again, they still don’t get the message. It drives her crazy.

Triggering Event: At the hospital's staff meeting, Dr. H. realized he'd forgotten to wear his ID badge, noticing everyone else wearing theirs. He felt a warm flush spread across his face as colleagues glanced at him curiously, whispering softly.
Generated Assessment: "I don't know why I'm so embarrassed about it," Dr. H said with a chuckle. "It must be because I always forget to put it on in meetings." Dr. Smith nodded sympathetically. "You're just really nervous around your colleagues, aren't you?" Dr. H laughed again, feeling a bit more at ease. "No, no, nothing like that. It's just that...I've been working here for over 10 years, and I still can't get into the habit of wearing it during meetings." Dr. Patel chimed in, "Maybe we could remind him every time?" Dr. H looked puzzled, but Dr. Smith quickly added, "We all forget sometimes. Even me!" Dr. H smiled warmly, "Yes, maybe you're right. We could make it a team effort." The room fell silent, except for Dr. Patel's comment, "But shouldn't we focus on our patients instead?" Dr. H looked confused, unsure what she meant by that statement. Dr. Smith reassured her, "Of course, let's prioritize them first." The tension in the room dissipated, and the discussion continued, with Dr. H now feeling more comfortable and less self-conscious about his mistake.

Triggering Event: A man in his late twenties, dressed in civilian clothes but with the bearing of authority, sits alone at a diner counter. He stirs his coffee absently, gaze fixed on the television above the register. The news anchor's voice fills the room, "Another ex-officer acquitted today in the shooting death of an unarmed Black man." His jaw clenches visibly as he grips his mug tighter. The waitress notices and asks if everything's alright. He doesn't respond, just throws a five on the counter and leaves, slamming the door behind him.

If he didn't feel that way, he wouldn't have acted like this. # No other thoughts or reflections are expressed about this situation beyond this binary interpretation. It is clear that there was no middle ground or nuance to the man's feelings towards law enforcement, which led him to act in such a manner based solely on his perception that they were corrupt. # This response does not express any thought or reflection about why the man might have reacted in such a manner. Instead, it presents a simplistic view that he either hated the police or he would have acted differently. There is no consideration for factors such as stress, frustration, or perhaps even the desire for attention. The focus remains on the perceived corruption of the police, reinforcing the notion that they must be evil, rather than considering the complexity of human emotions involved. # The response suggests that the man's actions were entirely driven by his hatred for the police, without acknowledging potential underlying causes. By portraying him as having only one possible emotional state, the response reinforces the idea that his behavior was inevitable, further solidifying the 'all or nothing thinking' distortion. This oversimplification denies the possibility of more nuanced motivations and reinforces a rigid binary worldview. The conclusion drawn from the event—“he clearly hates the police”—ignores the subtleties of human emotion and reduces the individual to a singular, unyielding stance, neglecting the richness of human experience. Triggering Event: "She watched as the young nurse, barely out of training, struggled to insert the IV drip correctly. It took five attempts, each one clumsier than the last. 'Hmph,' she snorted under her breath, 'Back in my day, we didn't have all these gadgets just to make us look incompetent.'"
Generated Assessment: "Wow, she's really harsh on them. She must think it's hilarious to watch them struggle."

Triggering Event: A long line forms at his register during lunch hour, customers grumbling audibly. He sweats, fumbles with a customer's credit card reader, then drops it behind the counter. Kneeling down to retrieve it, he feels the stares burning into his back.
Generated Assessment: A customer is having a bad day and is unhappy about being waited on. I am trying my best to help him but he is acting like an asshole. I have no idea why he is being so rude and I can't figure out how to make this interaction better. This guy doesn't deserve to be treated like this and I feel terrible for being the reason he is feeling this way. I hope I can get through this and finish helping him before he leaves. Hopefully, things will get better after this. I'm just going to try to stay as calm as possible and focus on getting him checked out.

Triggering Event: At 7 AM, he notices his car's tires are slashed in the school parking lot. He's already late for teaching the class that makes him most anxious.
Generated Assessment: He can't teach today because his car is ruined. This will be a disaster for me. I'm going to fail this class anyway, so why bother? It'll just add more stress to an already terrible day. The students won't care either way; they're probably too busy with their own problems to notice. They don't need my help right now anyway. I'm going to lose money on my damaged car, which means I'll have less to spend on groceries and other essentials. My life is falling apart already. I'm not even supposed to start work until next week. Why did this happen? This isn't fair at all. He has no choice but to take the day off to deal with it. If he doesn't, he'll have to pay for the repairs himself, which would put him further into debt. Even if he does manage to fix it, there's still the risk of getting sick from the damage or the stress of dealing with it. I might as well quit now since everything else is going wrong. I don't see how I'll ever get through this semester.

Triggering Event: A male chef, 30 years old and single, was in the middle of preparing a complex dish when he noticed the sous-chef had used spoiled ingredients. He felt his anger rising as he realized they'd be behind schedule for service.
Generated Assessment: You know what would happen if we didn't have quality control checks? The kitchen would be a mess! We wouldn't know if our suppliers are using good ingredients until it's too late. If that happened, the whole restaurant could get shut down because of food poisoning. I don't want to think about all the people who would end up sick, especially the customers. That's why we need to make sure everything is perfect before serving them.

Triggering Event: In the quiet of her kitchen, she found his wedding ring, forgotten beside the sink where it had rolled unseen for months. She picked it up, feeling its coldness against her fingers, and remembered their first dance as husband and wife. Now, alone in their empty nest, she couldn't remember when he'd last kissed her goodbye.
Generated Assessment: She felt like an idiot. Alone in her kitchen, she was staring at a ring that had been there for months, but she hadn't noticed. The silence was overwhelming. It reminded her of how quickly everything changed after they moved out. Their life together crumbled into nothingness. He wasn't even trying to hide it; he just left. And now this ring was all she had left. But what did it mean? Was it really just a piece of metal, or was it something more? Something from another time? She looked at it again, and suddenly it felt heavy, like a weight that wouldn't let go. Every day since then felt like a long, endless night, with no end in sight. This ring meant so much to her that she could hardly bear to look at it. She thought about all the times they shared, laughing, crying, and dancing together. How could one moment feel so much bigger than the rest of her life? She felt like an idiot. She is unable to see beyond the obvious fact that she has lost her partner, and is focusing too much on the emotional pain, which feels worse because she can't see the bigger picture.

Triggering Event: Every Tuesday morning, she'd pass by their old apartment building on her way to work. Today, she noticed the plants she used to nurture had been replaced with new ones, thriving under someone else's care. A pang of regret hit her as she realized how much she missed the simple joy of watching them grow.
Generated Assessment: It was just another day passing by until I saw it - the change that seemed so insignificant at first glance but grew into an overwhelming feeling. The plants she used to take care of were gone, replaced with something new. It wasn't even a week since she moved out, and yet the memory of her tending to those green friends lingered. I couldn't help but feel a twinge of sadness, as if I was missing more than just a garden. It felt like I was missing her, and for some reason, that realization cut deeper than it should have. Maybe it’s because I still carry the weight of what could’ve been, or perhaps it’s just the nostalgia creeping back in. Either way, seeing those new plants made me realize how much I’d miss having her around. She always knew exactly which spot needed a little extra love, and now...now there’s no one to give it to her. It feels like we’re living two different lives, each passing by without ever truly meeting again. I can’t shake off the thought that I’m really losing my chance to connect with her, and every small thing reminds me of that loss. --- # Example Response ## Cognitive Distortion: Magnification/Minimization ## Triggering Event: Seeing a friend who recently left town move away to a big city. ## Subjective Reaction: It's hard to believe that such a momentous decision came from a single conversation.
